So the first observation is that identity, while interesting in itself, is also a very tricky concept, whereas from the point of view of entailment what we are mainly interested in is not so much identity, but equivalents right?
So an identity relation is also an equivalence relation, but the equivalent properties are actually what we use in entailment, so that's the being symmetric, transitive and reflexive.
That's actually what we use in all the owl deductions, so the identity relation is.
Not just any equivalence relation, it's actually the smallest equivalence relation.
And then there's another insight the other way round.
Not a new finding, by the way, this is from a paper from the 1950s finding by philosopher Quine.
Quine states that every equivalence is also an identity relation.
